KE / Domain: Hospital admissions and emergency department visits
AOP entity (KE/KER): AO: Lung function, decreased (Event 11); Organism-level adverse outcome; clinical endpoint of respiratory disease
Input (manipulation / sample): Population-level epidemiological data; electronic health records; administrative claims data; patient cohorts with respiratory conditions (asthma, COPD, pneumonia)
Method / Assay (SOP notes): Epidemiological analysis of hospital admission and ED visit rates. ICD coding for respiratory diagnoses. Time-series analysis for temporal trends. Risk factor assessment (environmental exposures, comorbidities). Statistical modeling (Poisson regression, case-crossover designs). Geographic and demographic stratification.
Output / Measurement: Hospital admission rates (per 100,000 population); ED visit rates; Respiratory diagnosis-specific admissions (ICD codes); Temporal trends; Association with environmental exposures or interventions; Risk ratios and odds ratios; Population-attributable fractions
Interpretation / Context fields to captu: Study population characteristics (age, sex, race/ethnicity, SES); geographic region; time period; ICD code versions and definitions; inclusion/exclusion criteria; exposure assessment methods; confounder adjustment variables; statistical model specification; data source (EHR, claims, registries)
Exemplar peer-reviewed manuscripts: Dhingra et al. (2023). [Hospital admissions and ED visits for respiratory conditions].
Protocol / SOP notes (attach): Document study design, population definition, outcome ascertainment (ICD codes), exposure assessment, confounder measurement, statistical analysis plan, sensitivity analyses, quality control for data completeness and accuracy
S&T considerations (ontology / mapping): Biolink: PopulationOutcome; OBI: epidemiological study; Mapping: AO lung function decrease, clinical manifestations; ICD codes for respiratory conditions; Population health; Clinical translation

KE / Domain: Emergency department visits for respiratory exacerbations
AOP entity (KE/KER): AO: Lung function, decreased (Event 11); acute respiratory events requiring medical care
Input (manipulation / sample): ED visit data; respiratory exacerbation cohorts (asthma, COPD); environmental exposure data
Method / Assay (SOP notes): Analysis of ED visit patterns for respiratory exacerbations. Case-control or cohort study designs. Exposure-outcome associations (air pollution, allergens, weather). Temporal analysis (seasonal patterns, acute exposure windows). Severity assessment (hospitalization from ED, ICU admission). Multivariate regression modeling.
Output / Measurement: ED visit rates for respiratory conditions; Exacerbation severity metrics; Association with short-term environmental exposures; Temporal patterns (daily, seasonal); Stratification by age, disease severity, medication use
Interpretation / Context fields to captu: Study population; ED catchment area; respiratory diagnosis definitions; exposure data sources (air quality monitors, satellite data); time-activity patterns; lag structures; effect modifiers; model covariates; validation of diagnoses
Exemplar peer-reviewed manuscripts: Jardel et al. (2024). [ED visits for respiratory exacerbations].
Protocol / SOP notes (attach): Include study protocol, outcome definitions, exposure assessment methods, confounder data collection, statistical modeling approach, sensitivity analyses for exposure windows and model specification
S&T considerations (ontology / mapping): Biolink: PopulationOutcome; OBI: case-control or cohort study; Mapping: AO respiratory exacerbation; Environmental health; Acute exposure-response; Clinical outcome

KE / Domain: Wildfire smoke exposure and respiratory hospitalizations
AOP entity (KE/KER): AO: Lung function, decreased (Event 11); environmental exposure leading to respiratory adverse outcomes
Input (manipulation / sample): Population in wildfire-affected regions; hospital admission data during wildfire events; air quality monitoring data (PM2.5, PM10)
Method / Assay (SOP notes): Quasi-experimental or time-stratified case-crossover design. Linkage of air quality data (wildfire smoke PM2.5) to health outcomes. Analysis of respiratory hospitalizations during wildfire vs non-wildfire periods. Distributed lag models for exposure-lag-response. Subgroup analysis by age, pre-existing conditions. Spatial analysis of exposure gradients.
Output / Measurement: Respiratory hospitalization rates; Relative risk or odds ratio per unit increase in PM2.5; Lag-response relationships; Population-attributable risk from wildfire smoke; Subgroup-specific effects (children, elderly, asthma/COPD patients)
Interpretation / Context fields to captu: Geographic region and wildfire events; air quality monitoring network; PM2.5 measurement and wildfire source attribution; hospital data source; respiratory outcome definitions (ICD codes); study period; exposure assessment (residential proximity, ambient monitoring, satellite AOD); confounders (temperature, humidity, day-of-week); model specification
Exemplar peer-reviewed manuscripts: Ruwan et al. [Wildfire smoke and respiratory hospitalizations].
Protocol / SOP notes (attach): Document wildfire event definition, air quality data sources and QC, health data linkage methods, exposure assignment approach, statistical modeling (case-crossover or time-series), sensitivity analyses, validation of wildfire smoke attribution
S&T considerations (ontology / mapping): Biolink: PopulationOutcome; OBI: environmental epidemiology study; Mapping: AO respiratory hospitalization; ENVO: wildfire smoke exposure, PM2.5; Environmental health; Climate-health linkage

KE / Domain: Wildfire air pollution and respiratory emergency visits
AOP entity (KE/KER): AO: Lung function, decreased (Event 11); acute respiratory effects of wildfire smoke
Input (manipulation / sample): Population cohorts; ED visit and hospitalization data; wildfire smoke exposure assessment
Method / Assay (SOP notes): Analysis of respiratory ED visits and hospitalizations associated with wildfire smoke events. Exposure modeling using air quality data, satellite observations, chemical transport models. Time-series or case-crossover designs. Assessment of vulnerable populations. Examination of specific respiratory conditions (asthma exacerbation, COPD exacerbation, pneumonia, bronchitis).
Output / Measurement: ED visit and hospitalization rates; Condition-specific outcome rates (asthma, COPD, etc.); Exposure-response functions for wildfire PM; Effect modification by age, SES, pre-existing disease; Attributable burden estimates
Interpretation / Context fields to captu: Study area and wildfire seasons; health data sources; respiratory outcome classifications; exposure metrics (daily PM2.5, wildfire-specific PM); exposure-lag windows; confounding factors; vulnerable population definitions; statistical model choice; uncertainty quantification
Exemplar peer-reviewed manuscripts: Wettstein et al. [Wildfire air pollution and respiratory emergency visits].
Protocol / SOP notes (attach): Include exposure assessment methodology (monitoring data, modeling, satellite), health outcome ascertainment, population risk stratification, statistical analysis protocol, sensitivity analyses for exposure metrics and model structure, uncertainty analysis
S&T considerations (ontology / mapping): Biolink: PopulationOutcome; OBI: time-series or case-crossover study; Mapping: AO respiratory ED visits/hospitalizations; ENVO: wildfire smoke, particulate matter; Public health impact; Vulnerable populations; Attributable risk
